Term.Name: text/vnd.IPTC.NITF
Term.Definition: IPTC News Industry Text Format NITF)

Term.Name: Optical Media
Term.Definition: Publication stored on optical storage medium

Term.Name: Magnetic Media
Term.Definition: Publication stored on magnetic storage medium

Term.Name: D2
Term.Definition: Publication stored on D2(uncompressed composite SDTV) tape

Term.Name: D3
Term.Definition: Publication stored on D3(uncompressed composite SDTV) tape

Term.Name: D5
Term.Definition: Publication stored on D5(uncompressed composite SDTV) tape

Term.Name: HD-D5
Term.Definition: Publication stored on HD-D5(compressed component HDTV) tape

Term.Name: D6
Term.Definition: Publication stored on D6(uncompressed composite HDTV) tape

Term.Name: D7
Term.Definition: Publication stored on D7(compressed component SDTV, DVCPRO, DVCPRO50) tape

Term.Name: D9
Term.Definition: Publication stored on D9(compressed component SDTV, DV based, Digital-S) tape

Term.Name: D10
Term.Definition: Publication stored on D10(BetaCAM IMX, compressed component SDTV, MPEG2 422 profile) tape

Term.Name: D11
Term.Definition: Publication stored on D11(HDCAM, compressed component HDTV) tape

Term.Name: D12
Term.Definition: Publication stored on D12(DVCPRO/HD, compressed component HDTV, DV based) tape

Term.Name: BetaCAM SX
Term.Definition: Publication stored on BetaCAM SX(compressed component SDTV, MPEG2 422profile) tape

Term.Name: 1-inch HDTV
Term.Definition: Publication stored on 1-inch HDTV(uncompressed component HDTV) tape

Term.Name: DV
Term.Definition: Publication stored on Digital Video tape

Term.Name: DVCPRO
Term.Definition: Publication stored on DVCPRO (compressed component SDTV, DV based) tape

Term.Name: DVCPRO50
Term.Definition: Publication stored on DVCPRO50 (compressed component SDTV, DV based) tape

Term.Name: DVCPRO/P
Term.Definition: Publication stored on DVCPRO/P (compressed component SDTV, DV based, progressive) tape

Term.Name: DVCAM
Term.Definition: Publication stored on DVCAM (compressed component SDTV, ISO/IEC DIF compliant) tape

Term.Name: Digital BetaCAM
Term.Definition: Publication stored on Digital BetaCAM(compressed component SDTV) tape

Term.Name: CassetteTape
Term.Definition: Publication stored on Audio Cassette Tape

Term.Name: DAT
Term.Definition: Publication stored on Digital Audio Tape

Term.Name: SD Memory Card
Term.Definition: Publication stored on SD Memory Card

Term.Name: MPEG-4 TwinVQ
Term.Definition: MPEG-4 Transform-domain Weighted Interleave Vector Quantization

Term.Name: SSACJM
Term.Definition: The single stimulus adjectival categorical judgement methods

Term.Name: SSNUCJM
Term.Definition: The single stimulus numerical categorical judgement methods

Term.Name: SCACJM
Term.Definition: The stimulus comparison adjectival categorical judgement methods

Term.Name: SCNCJM
Term.Definition: The stimulus comparison non-categorical judgment methods

Term.Name: SSCQE
Term.Definition: The single stimulus continuous quality evaluation

Term.Name: SDSCE
Term.Definition: The simultaneous double stimulus for continuous evaluation method

Term.Name: HVS_R
Term.Definition: Human vision system model with reference

Term.Name: HVS_NR
Term.Definition: Human vision system model with no reference

Term.Name: Error blocks
Missing blocks
Term.Definition: Missing blocks due to packet loss

Term.Name: Anchor
Anchorman
Anchorwoman
Anchorperson
Term.Definition: A television reporter who coordinates a broadcast to which several correspondents contribute.

Term.Name: Reporter
Newsman
Newswoman
Newsperson
Term.Definition: A person who gathers news and other journalistic material and writes or broadcasts it-the basic job in journalism.

Term.Name: Interviewer
Term.Definition: A person who conducts an interview.

Term.Name: Narrator
Storyteller
Term.Definition: A person who tells a story.

Term.Name: Actor
Actress
Histrion
Player
Thespian
Role Player
Term.Definition: A person who plays the role of a character.

Term.Name: Musician
Instrumentalist
Player
Term.Definition: Someone who plays a musical instrument (as a profession).

Term.Name: Performer
Performing Artist
Term.Definition: An entertainer who performs a dramatic or musical work for audience. (Other than above).

Term.Name: Executive Producer
Executive in Charge of Production
Term.Definition: A producer who is not involved in any technical aspects of the making process, but who is still responsible for the overall production. Typically an executive producer handles business and legal issues.

Term.Name: Producer
Term.Definition: The manager of an event, show, or other work, usually the individual in charge of finance, personnel, and other non-artistic aspects in the development of commercials, plays, movies, and other works.

Term.Name: Scriptwriter
Term.Definition: A person who writes scripts for plays or movies or broadcast dramas.

Term.Name: Director
Term.Definition: A supervisor; generally refers to the person responsible for all audience-visible components of a program, film, or show, whereas the producer is responsible for the financial and other behind-the- scenes aspects. A director's duties might also include casting, script editing, shot selection, shot composition, and editing.

Term.Name: Assistant Director
AD
Term.Definition: An assistant director's duties include tracking the progress of filming versus the production schedule, and preparing call sheets that is a listing of which actors will be required for which scenes, and when they will be required.

Term.Name: Production Assistant
PA
Term.Definition: A person who aids a producer, director, assistant director, or others involved in film or TV production, such as the person who keeps passersby from waking into a location shoot.

Term.Name: Continuity Person
Term.Definition: A person who writes a detailed script used making a film in order to avoid discontinuities from shot to shot.

Term.Name: Timekeeper
Production Associate
Term.Definition: A person who keeps track of the time elapsed in a program.

Term.Name: Music Supervisor
Term.Definition: A person who coordinates the work of the composer, the editor, and sound mixers.

Term.Name: Composer
Term.Definition: A musician whose music appears in a program's score. Most movies have at least some original music written for the score, usually after the relevant parts of the movie have been filmed.

Term.Name: Production Designer
Term.Definition: An artist responsible for designing the overall visual appearance of a program.

Term.Name: Art Director
Term.Definition: A person who oversees the artists and craftspeople who build the sets.

Term.Name: Set Designer
Term.Definition: A person responsible for designing sets. The set designer reports to the art director.

Term.Name: Set Maker
Term.Definition: A person who makes the set with the specifications dictated by the set designer.

Term.Name: Property Master
Prop Master
Props
Property
Term.Definition: A person responsible for buying/acquiring any props needed for a production.

Term.Name: Property Assistant
Prop Assistant
Term.Definition: Responsible for the placement and maintenance of props on a set.

Term.Name: Sound Effects Person
Soundman
Sound Person
SE
Term.Definition: The sound-effects person, generally called a soundman, is responsible for the sound effects, or sounds other than music and human voices.

Term.Name: Special Effects Supervisor
Special Effects Co-Ordinator
Term.Definition: The chief of a production's special effects crew.

Term.Name: Special Effects Assistant
Special Effects Technician
Term.Definition: A person who makes an artificial effect used to create an illusion in a program.

Term.Name: Animator
Term.Definition: An artist who produces animation drawings, or the person in charge of an animation production.

Term.Name: Computer Graphics Artist
CG
Term.Definition: An artist who produces computer graphics.

Term.Name: Makeup Supervisor
Term.Definition: The decorations placed directly on the skin or hair of an actor for cosmetic or artistic effect. Practitioners are called artists or supervisors.

Term.Name: Makeup Artist
Term.Definition: The decorations placed directly on the skin or hair of an actor for cosmetic or artistic effect. Practitioners are called artists or supervisors.

Term.Name: Costume Supervisor
Term.Definition: A person responsible for handling the costumes worn by actors.

Term.Name: Costumer
Wardrobe
Assistant Wardrobe
Wardrobe Assistant
Term.Definition: A person who handles the costumes worn by actors.

Term.Name: Technical Director
TD
Term.Definition: The director of the technical facilities for a production.

Term.Name: Switcher
Term.Definition: A person (studio engineer) responsible for camera mixing or switching. Switching is the selection process among the various audio and video sources in a production.

Term.Name: Camera Operator
Cameraperson
Cameraman
Term.Definition: A person who operates the camera to the specifications dictated by the director.

Term.Name: Camera Assistant
Assistant Camera
Term.Definition: A member of the camera crew who assists the camera operator.

Term.Name: Lighting Supervisor
Term.Definition: The chief of a production's lightning crew.

Term.Name: Lighting Operator
Lighting Technician
Term.Definition: A technician who installs, operates, and maintains lighting.

Term.Name: Sound Supervisor
Recording Supervisor
Term.Definition: The person responsible for the technical quality of a program's sound.

Term.Name: Sound Engineer
Audio Operator
Term.Definition: A person who operates sound recording devices.

Term.Name: Visual Effects Supervisor
Video Supervisor
Term.Definition: The chief of a production's visual effects crew.

Term.Name: Video Engineer
Video Operator
Term.Definition: An engineer who operates the monitors and camera control units to switch from one camera to another and maintain color, contrast, and other visual qualities.

Term.Name: Transportation Captain
Term.Definition: A person who drives either equipment or passenger trucks, typically between location shootings, sets, and the studio.

Term.Name: Staff
Production Staff
Term.Definition: Personnel who carries out an assigned production task. (Other than above).

Term.Name: Non-fiction
Term.Definition: All programs dealing with facts, situations, opinions, theories and forecasts

Term.Name: Bulletin
Term.Definition: Program with formal desk presentation, usually interspersed with visual material.

Term.Name: Magazine
Term.Definition: Program consisting of separate items which has at least one common quality and presented under one main heading.

Term.Name: Commented event
Term.Definition: An outside event covered by the broadcaster and with an accompanying commentary, and transmitted live or deferred (within 24 hours)

Term.Name: Documentary
Term.Definition: Program concerning a single theme, involving descriptive and/or interpretative commentaries, illustrations, interviews, statements, photos or other documentation.

Term.Name: Discussion/Interview/Debate
Term.Definition: Mainly verbal program in which more than one person participates.

Term.Name: Lecture/Speech/Presentation
Term.Definition: Mainly verbal program in which only one person participates.

Term.Name: Textual (incl. relayed teletext)
Term.Definition: Program consisting only of alphanumerical information.

Term.Name: Theatre/Cinema
Term.Definition: Program about subject concerning the world of film and cinema, e.g. preview of recent films

Term.Name: Advertising
Term.Definition: Program about (the world of) advertising, e.g. interview with advertising people

Term.Name: Drama
Term.Definition: Program consisting of a prose or verse composition telling a story, for performance by actors, puppets or in animated form

Term.Name: Performed drama
Term.Definition: Program consisting of a dramatic work, performed by live actors

Term.Name: Readings
Term.Definition: Programs consisting of readings of poems, stories or other literary works

Term.Name: Drama with puppets
Term.Definition: Program consisting of a dramatic work, performed with puppets (e.g. The Muppet Show)

Term.Name: Animated drama
Term.Definition: Program consisting of a dramatic work, presented as an animation (e.g. The Flintstones)

Term.Name: Hosted show
Term.Definition: Program that can be regarded neither as non-fiction nor as drama or music/dance and usually of a light entertainment character in which one or more persons fulfill the role of presenter, host, quiz or games master, announcer, chairperson or speaker.

Term.Name: Panel-show
Term.Definition: Program that can be regarded neither as non-fiction nor as drama or concert and normally of a light entertainment character in which is presented by a more or less fixed group of people (panel)

Term.Name: Standup comedian(s)
Term.Definition: Program performed by a single. a pair or a group of comedians

Term.Name: Solo performance
Term.Definition: Musical performance by one or more soloists accompanied by an ensemble

Term.Name: Small ensemble performance
Term.Definition: Musical performance by ensemble of less than 7 performers

Term.Name: Orchestral
Term.Definition: Musical performance by ensemble of more than 7 performers

Term.Name: Theatrical music
Term.Definition: Performance by vocalists and musicians in a theatrical work

Term.Name: Music
Term.Definition: Program about a musical subject (e.g. a biography of Mozart)

Term.Name: Ballet
Term.Definition: Program performed by (ballet) dancers (e.g. The Swan Lake, Jazz Ballet, etc.)

Term.Name: Infotainment
Term.Definition: Programs intended primarily to entertain, but which also contain substantial informative elements

Term.Name: Advice
Term.Definition: Program intended to advise about matters of personal interest, such as consumer prices and quality, financial matters, health, or, for the interest of special groups, weather or traffic information.

Term.Name: Track/field
Term.Definition: Collection of sports in athletic track and field

Term.Name: Horseracing/Government-sponsored sporting events (cycling, boat races, etc.)
Outdoors
Term.Definition: Sports just for fun or personal health

Term.Name: Music
Term.Definition: Program about a musical subject (not a program consisting of music)

Term.Name: Theater/Cinema
Term.Definition: Program about subject concerning the world of film and cinema (not a program consisting of films)

Term.Name: Humanities
Term.Definition: The branches of learning regarded as having primarily a cultural character and which usually include language, literature, history, mathematics and philosophy.

Term.Name: Applied sciences
Term.Definition: Sciences dealing with material phenomena or industrial processes.

Term.Name: Medicine
Term.Definition: Programs about medical subjects, health, etc.

Term.Name: Documentary
Term.Definition: Program concerning a single theme, involving descriptive and/or interpretative commentaries, illustrations, interviews, statements, photos or other documentation

Term.Name: Discussion
Term.Definition: Mainly verbal program in which more than one person participates

Term.Name: Lecture
Term.Definition: Mainly verbal program in which only one person participates

Term.Name: Textual (incl. relayed teletext)
Term.Definition: Program consisting only of alphanumeric information

Term.Name: Drama
Term.Definition: Program consisting of a prose or verse composition, resp. one telling a story, written for or as if for performance by actors, puppets or animated

Term.Name: Popular drama
Term.Definition: Drama written after approximately 1918 and without literary or cultural pretensions

Term.Name: Comedy
Term.Definition: Dramatized series in a humorous style and performed by a varying cast

Term.Name: "Broken" comedy
Term.Definition: Humorous and/or satirical program consisting of short dramatic sequences, sketches, performed by comedians (e.g. The Benny Hill Show, Monty Python, etc.)

Term.Name: Sitcom
Term.Definition: Dramatized series in a humorous style and performed by a more or less fixed cast

Term.Name: Soap
Term.Definition: Dramatized serial program dealing with easy- to-grasp situations performed by a limited cast

Term.Name: Medical melodrama
Term.Definition: Drama production situated in hospitals and/or dealing with medical subjects

Term.Name: Legal melodrama
Term.Definition: Drama production where the primary action takes place in law courts and/or law firms

Term.Name: Epic
Term.Definition: Dramatized narrative about the deeds of a traditional or historical hero or heroes and/or dealing with or characterized by events of historical or legendary importance

Term.Name: Serious drama
Term.Definition: Drama with literary and/or cultural value

Term.Name: Contemporary drama
Term.Definition: Drama written after approximately 1918 and with literary and/or cultural value.

Term.Name: Docudrama
Term.Definition: Drama based upon reality sometimes with documentary inserts

Term.Name: Readings
Term.Definition: Programs consisting of readings of stories or other literary works

Term.Name: Performed drama
Term.Definition: Program consisting of a dramatic work, performed by live actors

Term.Name: Drama with puppets
Term.Definition: Program consisting of a dramatic work, performed with puppets(e.g. The Muppet Show)

Term.Name: Animated drama
Term.Definition: Program consisting of a dramatic work, presented as an animation (e.g. the Flintstones)

Term.Name: Informative entertainment
Term.Definition: Programs intended primarily to entertain but with substantial informative elements

Term.Name: Hosted show
Term.Definition: Program that can be regarded neither as non-fiction nor as drama or music/dance and usually of a light entertainment character in which one or more persons fulfill the role of presenter, host, quiz or games master, announcer, chairperson or speaker

Term.Name: Panel-show
Term.Definition: Program that can be regarded neither as non-fiction nor as drama or concert and normally of a light entertainment character in which is presented by a more or less fixed group of people (panel)

Term.Name: Simple game show
Term.Definition: Competition of a pure entertainment character (normally contest) of low production value

Term.Name: Big game show
Term.Definition: Competition of a pure entertainment character (normally contest) of high production value

Term.Name: Quiz/Contest
Term.Definition: Competitions calling into play the competitors' special knowledge and intelligence and/or which involve considerable production work and form part of a broadcaster's mission in the fields of cultural formation and education

Term.Name: Variety show
Term.Definition: Program with various performers such as comedians, magicians, singers, etc.

Term.Name: Humor
Term.Definition: Program without sketches or "broken drama", consisting (mainly) of verbal jokes, gags, bloopers, etc.

Term.Name: Comedy
Term.Definition: Program without sketches or "broken drama", consisting (mainly) of verbal jokes, gags, bloopers, etc.

Term.Name: Stand-up comedian(s)
Term.Definition: Program performed by one or more stand-up comedians

Term.Name: Music
Term.Definition: Example: Ballet "The Swan Lake" should be classified as "serious music, classical/romantic"

Term.Name: Serious music
Term.Definition: Serious music including chamber, instrumental, operatic, symphonic, choral and sacred music.

Term.Name: Early
Term.Definition: Music written before the middle of the 17th Century

Term.Name: Classical and Romantic
Term.Definition: Serious music from the middle of the 18th until the end of the 19th Century

Term.Name: Contemporary
Term.Definition: Serious music written during the 20th Century

Term.Name: Ballet
Term.Definition: TV programs (predominantly) consisting of music, dance or ballet

Term.Name: Jazz
Term.Definition: Indigenous American popular music, born in New Orleans of African slaves social circumstances. The jazz idiom is characterized by certain syncopations over strongly reiterated rhythms in which improvisation plays an important part.

Term.Name: Middle-of-the-road
Term.Definition: Music which, in varying circumstances, gives pleasure to the widest possible spectrum of the music-loving audience

Term.Name: Pop
Term.Definition: The most central and widely circulated types of popular music, in particular rock and roll, reggae, etc.

Term.Name: Ethnic
Term.Definition: Music which has not changed throughout the course of history and is normally played on traditional instruments e.g. Raga in India or koto in Japan

Term.Name: World music
Term.Definition: Commercial music based on traditional music mainly from the Caribbean, and often using new instruments such as synthesizers

Term.Name: Folk
Term.Definition: Music that is the product of a tradition that has been evolved through the process of oral transmission

Term.Name: Rock
Term.Definition: The most central and widely circulated types of popular music, in particular rock and roll, reggae, etc.

Term.Name: Pop-rock
Term.Definition: The most central and widely circulated types of popular music, in particular rock and roll, reggae, etc.

Term.Name: Enrichment
Term.Definition: Program primarily intended to increase knowledge about non-current subjects in a didactic or non-didactic way, or to religiously inspire (e.g. travelogues, war documentaries, educational programs, religious programs)

Term.Name: General enrichment
Term.Definition: Program primarily intended to increase knowledge about non-current subjects in a non-didactic way

Term.Name: Inspirational enrichment
Term.Definition: Program based on different forms of religious beliefs or intended to edify the audience

Term.Name: Education
Term.Definition: Program primarily intended to increase knowledge about non-current subjects in a explicitly didactic way

Term.Name: Effect movies
Term.Definition: Monster Movies, Live Action Hero, etc.

Term.Name: Entertainment
Term.Definition: Program intended primarily to evoke relaxation, feelings of pleasure and/or awareness of beauty

Term.Name: Informative entertainment
Term.Definition: Program primarily intended to increase knowledge about non-current subjects in a didactic or non-didactic way, or to religiously inspire

Term.Name: Information
Term.Definition: Program intended primarily to inform about current facts, situations, events, theories or forecasts, or to provide explanatory background information and advice

Term.Name: Infotainment
Term.Definition: Program primarily intended to increase knowledge about non-current subjects in a didactic or non-didactic way, or to religiously inspire

Term.Name: Advice
Term.Definition: Program primarily intended to increase knowledge about non-current subjects in a didactic or non-didactic way, or to religiously inspire

Term.Name: Enrichment
Term.Definition: Program primarily intended to increase knowledge about non-current subjects in a didactic or non-didactic way, or to religiously inspire

Term.Name: Involvement
Term.Definition: Program intended to involve people in social action, such as fund raising, good causes etc.

Term.Name: Main keyword
Term.Definition: Program primarily intended to increase knowledge about non-current subjects in a didactic or non-didactic way, or to religiously inspire.

Term.Name: Sub keyword
Term.Definition: Program primarily intended to increase knowledge about non-current subjects in a didactic or non-didactic way, or to religiously inspire.

Term.Name: Keywords
Term.Definition: Program primarily intended to increase knowledge about non-current subjects in a didactic or non-didactic way, or to religiously inspire.

Term.Name: General audience
Term.Definition: Programs not intended for a specific target group

Term.Name: Age groups
Term.Definition: The age group levels for which the program is primarily intended

Term.Name: Ethnic groups
Term.Definition: Program for native-born people differing in language and/or culture

Term.Name: Immigrant groups
Term.Definition: Program for non-native born people and their immediate descendants, differing in language and/or culture

Term.Name: PG12
Term.Definition: It is desirable for those under 12 to be accompanied by parent or adult guardian.

Term.Name: R-15
Term.Definition: Nobody under 15 is admitted because of inappropriate content.

Term.Name: R-18
Term.Definition: Nobody under 18 is admitted because of inappropriate content.

Term.Name: Level4
Term.Definition: Crude, vulgar language or extreme hate speech

Term.Name: PG
Term.Definition: Parental guidance suggested (Some material may not be suitable for children)

Term.Name: PG-13
Term.Definition: Parents strongly cautioned (Some material may be inappropriate for children under 13)

Term.Name: R
Term.Definition: Restricted (Under 17 requires accompanying parent of adult guardian)

Term.Name: Parental advisory
Term.Definition: Strong language or depictions of violence, sex or substance abuse. Parental discretion is advised.

Term.Name: Level 4
Term.Definition: Explicit sexual acts or sex crimes

Term.Name: Level 0
Term.Definition: None of the above or innocent kissing; romance

Term.Name: TVY
Term.Definition: All children. (This program is designed to be appropriate for all children. Whether animated or live-action, the themes and elements in this program are specifically designed for a very young audience, including children from ages 2 - 6. This program is not expected to frighten younger children.)

Term.Name: TVY7
Term.Definition: Directed to older children. (This program is designed for children age 7 and above. It may be more appropriate for children who have acquired the developmental skills needed to distinguish between make-believe and reality. Themes and elements in this program may include mild fantasy violence or comedic violence, or may frighten children under the age of 7. Therefore, parents may wish to consider the suitability of this program for their very young children. Note: For those programs where fantasy violence may be more intense or more combative than other programs in this category, such programs will be designated TV-Y7-FV.)

Term.Name: TVG
Term.Definition: General Audience. (Most parents would find this program suitable for all ages. Although this rating does not signify a program designed specifically for children, most parents may let younger children watch this program unattended. It contains little or no violence, no strong language and little or no sexual dialogue or situations.)

Term.Name: TVPG
Term.Definition: Parental guidance suggested. (This program contains material that parents may find unsuitable for younger children. Many parents may want to watch it with their younger children. The theme itself may call for parental guidance and/or the program contains one or more of the following: moderate violence (V), some sexual situations (S), infrequent coarse language (L), or some suggestive dialogue (D).)

Term.Name: TV14
Term.Definition: Parents strongly cautioned. (This program contains some material that many parents would find unsuitable for children under 14 years of age. Parents are strongly urged to exercise greater care in monitoring this program and are cautioned against letting children under the age of 14 watch unattended. This program contains one or more of the following: intense violence (V), intense sexual situations (S), strong coarse language (L), or intensely suggestive dialogue (D).)

Term.Name: TVMA
Term.Definition: Mature audience only. (This program is specifically designed to be viewed by adults and therefore may be unsuitable for children under 17. This program contains one or more of the following: graphic violence (V), explicit sexual activity (S), or crude indecent language (L).)

Term.Name: Level 3
Term.Definition: Aggressive violence or death to humans

Term.Name: Level 0
Term.Definition: None of the above or sports related

Term.Name: Terrestrial
Term.Definition: Publication available through a terrestrial channel

Term.Name: Optical Media
Term.Definition: Publication stored on optical storage medium

Term.Name: Magnetic Media
Term.Definition: Publication stored on magnetic storage medium

Term.Name: D2
Term.Definition: Publication stored on D2(uncompressed composite SDTV) tape

Term.Name: D3
Term.Definition: Publication stored on D3(uncompressed composite SDTV) tape

Term.Name: D5
Term.Definition: Publication stored on D5(uncompressed composite SDTV) tape

Term.Name: HD-D5
Term.Definition: Publication stored on HD-D5(compressed component HDTV) tape

Term.Name: D6
Term.Definition: Publication stored on D6(uncompressed composite HDTV) tape

Term.Name: D7
Term.Definition: Publication stored on D7(compressed component SDTV, DVCPRO, DVCPRO50) tape

Term.Name: D9
Term.Definition: Publication stored on D9(compressed component SDTV, DV based, Digital-S) tape

Term.Name: D10
Term.Definition: Publication stored on D10(BetaCAM IMX, compressed component SDTV, MPEG2 422 profile) tape

Term.Name: D11
Term.Definition: Publication stored on D11(HDCAM, compressed component HDTV) tape

Term.Name: D12
Term.Definition: Publication stored on D12(DVCPRO/HD, compressed component HDTV, DV based) tape

Term.Name: BetaCAM SX
Term.Definition: Publication stored on BetaCAM SX(compressed component SDTV, MPEG2 422profile) tape

Term.Name: 1-inch HDTV
Term.Definition: Publication stored on 1-inch HDTV(uncompressed component HDTV) tape

Term.Name: DV
Term.Definition: Publication stored on Digital Video tape

Term.Name: DVCPRO
Term.Definition: Publication stored on DVCPRO (compressed component SDTV, DV based) tape

Term.Name: DVCPRO50
Term.Definition: Publication stored on DVCPRO50 (compressed component SDTV, DV based) tape

Term.Name: DVCPRO/P
Term.Definition: Publication stored on DVCPRO/P (compressed component SDTV, DV based, progressive) tape

Term.Name: DVCAM
Term.Definition: Publication stored on DVCAM (compressed component SDTV, ISO/IEC DIF compliant) tape

Term.Name: Digital BetaCAM
Term.Definition: Publication stored on Digital BetaCAM(comressed component SDTV) tape

Term.Name: CassetteTape
Term.Definition: Publication stored on Audio Cassette Tape

Term.Name: DAT
Term.Definition: Publication stored on Digital Audio Tape

Term.Name: SD Memory Card
Term.Definition: Publication stored on SD Memory Card

Term.Name: Audio-Video
Term.Definition: Actions Related to Audio and Video

Term.Name: Record
Term.Definition: Record input stream to local storage media

Term.Name: Preview
Term.Definition: View or listen to a summary of the input stream

Term.Name: SkipForward
Term.Definition: Skip forward over a portion of the input stream

Term.Name: SkipBackward
Term.Definition: Skip backward over a portion of the input stream

Term.Name: SkipToEnd
Term.Definition: Go to the beginning of the input stream

Term.Name: SkipForward
Term.Definition: Go to the end of the input stream

Term.Name: CopyCD
Term.Definition: Copy all or parts of a CD

Term.Name: Zoom
Term.Definition: Zoom (in) to the on-screen image or sequence

Term.Name: SlowMotion
Term.Definition: View input stream in slow motion

Term.Name: ScrollUp
Term.Definition: Scroll up in a web page/composite page

Term.Name: ScrollDown
Term.Definition: Scroll down in a web page/composite page

Term.Name: Search
Term.Definition: Search the web or local resources

Term.Name: SubmitForm
Term.Definition: Submit a form with requested information

Term.Name: Archive
Term.Definition: Archive content to persistent local storage media

Term.Name: AddToWishList
Term.Definition: Designate a product or item as possible future purchasing item

Term.Name: AddToCart
Term.Definition: Designate a product or item as potential immediate purchase item

Term.Name: Cut
Term.Definition: A cut is an abrupt transition between two edited video segments. When the transition is a cut, the duration of the video segment representing the transition is 0.

Term.Name: Analog-Residual-Cut
Term.Definition: The transition is a cut that was not intended to be visible. Analog residual cuts are used to introduce gradual transition segments, or are caused by fixing the film when some frames of a movie have burnt in the projector. Sometimes, these cuts induce a change of luminosity and so they may be detectable.

Term.Name: Gradual
Term.Definition: The transition evolves progressively from an edited video segment to another one. A gradual transition can be a fade, a dissolve, or a wipe, among others.

Term.Name: Cross-dissolve
Term.Definition: The pixels values of the current frame are modified progressively to obtain the values of the pixels of the next frame.

Term.Name: Fade in
Term.Definition: The pixels values of the current frame are modified progressively to obtain the values of the pixels of the next frame. The evolution is made from a flat color to a complex scene.

Term.Name: Fade out
Term.Definition: The pixels values of the current frame are modified progressively to obtain the values of the pixels of the next frame. The evolution is made from a scene to a flat color.

Term.Name: Iris Opening
Term.Definition: The pixels of the new frame replace progressively the pixel of the current one. At the beginning the new pixels appear in a circle centered on the screen. The circle grows progressively taking all the screen and showing the new frame.

Term.Name: Iris Closing
Term.Definition: The pixels of the new frame replace progressively the pixel of the current one. At the beginning, the new pixels appear out of a circle centered on the screen. The circle decreases progressively until it disappears from the screen only the new frame can then be seen.

Term.Name: Wipe
Term.Definition: The pixels of the new frame appear progressively behind a line which crosses the whole screen on several consecutive frames.

Term.Name: Push wipe
Term.Definition: The pixels of the new frame appear progressively behind a line which crosses the whole screen on several consecutive frames. The last frames of the previous shot are moved out of the screen while the first frames of the new shot are moved in. Visually, the new frame seems to "push" the current one.
Indicates the intensity of the story complication
Indicates how a story is developing along the story timeline. Its peak depicts the climax of the story
